text: Colleagues, I am going to go ahead and start the meeting.
So good morning colleagues, this is the November 2, 2020 Council briefing.
It will come to order.
The time is 9:30 A.M.
Please call role.
Debora Juarez, Andrew J.
Lewis, Tammy J. Morales
Here.
Teresa Mosqueda
I am sorry.
Alex Pedersen
Here.
Kshama Sawant
Here
Dan Strauss
Here
Council President Lorena Gonzcez.
Lisa Herbold
Here
Debora Juarez
Here.
Are you present?
No, I am not.
Is there eight or nine?
There is nine present.
We are all accounted for this morning.
And safe Halloween weekend . Ul we are going to move into approval of minutes.
The minutes of October 26, 2020 will be adopted.
Hearing no objection, the minutes are adopted.
The President's report.
Good morning colleagues.
We have a long Council briefing today.
I will keep my President's report short . First, we have a very long agenda.
We will consider the payment of the bills, the introduction and referral calendar and 33 other items of business.
Most of those items on this afternoon's Council agenda our appointment for the Council's consideration.
We could move through them rather efficiently.
We will also accept public comment this afternoon.
This is consistent with the public agenda.
This will be no more than 20 minutes this afternoon.
Second, I wanted to acknowledge that in communities across the country, including here in Seattle, tomorrow Tuesday, November 3, 2020 is the last day to vote in our local and Federal elections.
First of all, please remember to vote by no later than 8:00 P.M.
Tomorrow Tuesday, November 3, 2020.
Please remember that ballots must be postmarked or deposited in an official election's office drop boxes by 8:00 P.M.
This Tuesday.
The city of Seattle like so many others has a historic number of people turning out to vote and officials predict that in Washington state, we will see a 90% voter turnout rate.
This is astonishing, impressive and inspiring.
I know many of our constituents are nervous on the outcome of the Presidential election in particular.
Many people across the city of Seattle are worried about the reaction that our fellow neighbors will have to election night results either tomorrow night or in the ensuing days.
It is critical for our constituents to know that the city is prepared and as always, local government will serve the people of Seattle no matter the outcome of the election.
Last week members of the Council received communication from the Mayor's office that was dated Friday, October 30, 2020 at 10:30 A.M.

In net, we were advised by the Mayor's office that quote as of this writing, the Seattle police Department and law enforcement agencies do not have any intelligence to indicate that there are any threats for election day or the days following.
Arc partners have not reported any threats or security issues that any ballot boxes.
As such, the police Department, fire Department and other agencies have been planning for contingency purposes only in order to be prepared for a wide range of scenarios.
Again, we all received that same communication on Friday, October 30.
This was in the morning at 10:30 A.M.
We really do encourage you all to take a look at that communication if you have had an opportunity to do so.
I know that we were all in the throes of select budget Committee on Friday.
We have missed that particular Email.

Again, for our constituents, it is really important that folks know that no matter what happens tomorrow, here in Seattle, we remain ready and prepared to serve all of our constituents and to make sure that we are helping each other in community.
Hopefully we will be in celebration of a strong Democratic showing for tomorrow's election day.
Again, just remember, please vote.
Please do so safely.
If you are going to the drop boxes, practice social distancing and wear a mask.
Again, those ballots that have to be in by 8:00 P.M.
Tomorrow in an official Dropbox or at an election office are important.
With that being said, that concludes the President's report.
I am happy to move into the first briefing item.
This is unless any of my colleagues have any opening remarks to make.
Hearing none, let's go ahead and dig into the first presentation for this morning.
This is a presentation of the state legislative agenda.
This morning, we are joined by the office of Intergovernmental relations.
We will discuss the city of saddle's 2021 state lobbying agenda.
This discussion will be the first of two briefing presentations related to the development of the agenda.
Today, the office of Intergovernmental relations will begin, excuse me, they will give us an overview of the process to develop the agenda.
We will begin discussing the legislative priorities the Council would like to have advanced by the office state lobbying team.
They will be joining us this morning.
Following today's discussion, we will have a second briefing in one month to review the draft agenda.
We will take final action at a city council meeting in December.
That is just a quick overview of the general process.
Oir will lead us through the particulars.
This includes how we can engage with Oir.
They are hard at work.
Let's go ahead and begin with a quick round of introductions from our state lobbying team.
Then I will hand it over to director Wilson to begin the presentation.
Good morning.
Good morning.
I am --
State relation's director.
I am the government relations program director.
I wanted to just start with a quick apology.
There is maintenance happening in my building.
Any loud noises, I apologize for that in advance.
We are before you with an update on the upcoming legislative session as we work through the process of drafting your 2021 legislative agenda.

I would like to thank many of you for taking the time to meet with us individually to review your specific legislative priorities for the upcoming session and for those of you who have not had the opportunity to hear from us yet, we will work to get something on the calendar very soon.
We will provide a little bit of the in-depth Timeline.
Once we have incorporated feedback from you all from today and our individual meetings, we will be before you again with a draft of the legislative agenda.
The goal is to adopt that agenda before the holiday recess.
This upcoming session will be unlike any session in the history of this state.
The challenges posed by Covid- 19 are enormous given the volume of legislators.
I know you have all figured out meetings at the city level.
The legislator is still working through some profound challenges Logistically as it relates to this upcoming session.
Robin will speak a little bit to that in her report.
This is in terms of how that will impact logistics, how you all engage and the volume of bills that they will move forward with this year.
Most importantly, I would like to start.
We have a new state legislative advocacy team.
I wanted to start with an introduction starting with Robin.
Many of you know her from her time at the office of housing.
She became the relation's director last year.
Many thanks to Robin and Emily Alvarado at the office of housing for supporting our work when we are looking to fill the role in a short time.
Now Robin has moved into our deputy director role given Cheryl Schwab's departure.
Quinn has experience in the Washington state legislator and formally as the state lobbyist.
They have moved into the state relation director role.
They are a state advocate . a big welcome to Quinn.
Thank you to Quinn and Dr.
Zimbabwe.
We are glad to have Quinn heading up the state program at Oir.
Last but not least, many of you have worked with Hannah Smith managing our Federal relations portfolio as the acting Federal relations director.
Now Hannah has graciously slipped it over to join the state lobby team as the government affairs program manager.
There have been many changes.
That being said, you can Email any of us and we will make sure that we are managing the right portfolio.
Lastly I wanted to recognize this moment in history and the Council's commitment to center our work in racial justice.

We are appreciative of the time that members and legislative leaders in the black caucus and members of the other caucus as well as the Senator and representative have taken a significant amount of time this interim to work through issues in the criminal justice and police reform portfolio.
Robin will review this next.
Thank you.
Good morning, everyone.
First, I thought I would just take this opportunity to talk a little bit more about the general overview as Lily said.
I think it is going to be a very different legislative session that we have ever seen before.
Hopefully, that will make it easier for members of Council to engage.
It will not be met necessary to go down to Olympia to testify or meet with legislators.
I am hoping that we can help you facilitate meetings much more easily during this session, especially when there are quite a few things that we really want to see happen this legislative session.
Lawmakers have been signaling that they are going to be very focused.
There will be a few issues in this session that will be almost entirely virtual.
Those three areas of focus are the budget of course.
It is related to Covid-19.
This has cause havoc on the state budget.
You are grappling with the impacts of that on the local level.
The state has a similar situation.
Coronavirus relief will be another area of focus.
Of course, as Lily mentioned, there is police reform.
Those three issues will be the things that will receive the most Airtime.
They will be the most likely to be able to advance this year.
As far as the budget is concerned, the revenue forecast that came in a few weeks ago was better than expected and better than what was forecasted in June.
There was nearly a $9 billion shortfall projected through 2023.
Now that has been cut in half to only 4.2 billion.
While that is a significant improvement, of course many things are quite tenuous with these budget forecasts.
Nobody is familiar with dealing with Covid-19 and a pandemic affecting the economy.
It is more optimistic but there are quite a few pressures on the budget.
The outcomes of the Federal elections will influence the potential stimulus funds received by the state.
It will impact the state budget.
Quinn will address progressive revenue later this morning.
We do know that lawmakers have said in terms of revenue, nothing is off the table.
They are looking at a range of options to raise progressive revenue for the state.
We understand that as far as the virtual session goes, the House will be fully remote.
The Senate will be a hybrid government and in person but mostly remote.
This slows the process down significantly.
Technological difficulties really present some issues.
Also, staffing, obviously, many legislative staff can be in a room together or down at the capital.
That has some impact.
During committee days in late September, there was only one hearing held at a time.
Of course, this significantly reduces the number of things that can happen during a normal session.
There is often four, five, six, 78 things going on at the same time.
I do not think they are entirely sure how everything is going to go.
I think we can just assume that the volume of what will happen is going to be much less than it would be in a normal year.

We are also being told that each legislative, each lawmaker will only, they are not essentially saying that you can't only introduce a number of bills but they are saying that you should really focus on two or three different proposals that you want to see advance rather than the many many that lawmakers often introduced in a regular long session.

We are also hearing that in order to proceed, unless it is in one these tab three areas of Coronavirus relief, budget, and police reform; there will be substantial agreement on proposals for them to move forward.
They are not going to want to waste a lot of time on the house or Senate floor to engage in controversial conversations in order to just get the normal business of the legislator done.
So all of those things add up to you know, I think us as a city, we need to be focused on what our priorities are so that we can hope to get things advanced this legislative session.
So if anybody else has any issues, I will pause for a moment.
If you have questions about the procedure and lay of the land, please speak.
Any questions?
It looks like there are not any Robin, proceed.
Thank you Council President.
I am going to move now to discussing police reform.
I want everyone to know that of course, you know, in the process of the setting of the legislative agenda, we ask all of the departments and agencies to submit their legislative priorities to us.
That process has happened.
We have incorporated all of their feedback into our legislative agenda.

That means that we have the community police Commission, the office of the inspector general, and the office of police accountability legislative agenda items incorporated into our police reform proposal.
We have heard that at the state level there are over 60 bills on police reform that have been introduced.
We also understand that there is an effort to collect things into omnibus bills to move things forward more easily and just have less proposals on the floor.
There is a focus on a number of different issue areas.
We are supportive of these in the city of Seattle.
Many of these things, we have already adopted.
You know, we are going to be probably looking into some other areas.

The issue areas that they are focusing on our tactics which is things like prohibiting no knock warrants, badge covering, banning the use of military equipment or the purchase of military equipment and limiting less lethal tactics of policing.
Training is another area of focus.
This includes things like De- escalation and implicit bias.
It includes technology so officers can access training from their cell phones on a daily basis.
Investigations and prosecutions of course, it is emerging as something with independent investigations, establishing an independent investigation agency.
We could create a special Prosecutor's office and perform post investigation audits.
The police funding aspect of things at the state level is a little bit different than it is at a local level.
They are looking at adding funding for programs that provide alternatives to policing.
That is difficult in a budget year when people are just trying to keep existing services that the state offers.
There are an explanation of things like lead and the sequential intercept model as well as expanding funding for behavioral health and looking at 911 Dispatchers.
There is a lot of work on accountability and transparency, decertification.

This includes and also an obligation to intervene, report, disciplinary action for lying on the stand or in a police report, and also mandating community accountability and public funding for public Database on police reform.

As I said, as we are supportive of all of these efforts at the state level, we also recognize that many of you are very focused on arbitration reforms as is the community police Commission, the office of the inspector general, and the office of police accountability.
This is as well as advocates in the community.
We plan to work in coalition with other Washington cities to address this issue and make sure that it is a significant point of conversation in Olympia.

Just to kind of closeout police reform, I would say that we understand that the decertification proposal that is being led by Senator Jamie Peterson and representative Goodman in the house is a significant area of focus for legislators.
It is a very significant piece of legislation.
It is 41 pages long.

It goes through all sorts of things on the decertification process from changing the mission of the criminal justice training Commission to expanding mandatory and discretionary Revocation criteria and even it changes the proof on disciplinary action to preponderance of the evidence.
Some significant changes are being looked at there for sure.
We are also hearing that qualified immunity, establishing a state class of action being led by representative Ty is a significant point of conversation.
So is independent investigations; we are waiting to see what the recommendations will be.
We are nearing to a close of those conversations.
There are two meetings this week.
We expect to see some proposals there.
And I am also going to shift to housing.
I will pause here to see if anybody has any questions on police reforms since it is such a significant issue for us this year.
Thank you Robin for that high level view of what you are hearing coming out of our state legislator.
I appreciate it.
Colleagues, any comments or questions for Robin as it relates to the police reform aspects of the report?
Councilmember Lisa Herbold, please.
As it relates to reform of the arbitration process, you mentioned that we will be working with other Washington cities to talk about how to advance that conversation.
Do you see that as being on a different Timeline or a different track from the state legislative agenda?
I recall that I had heard that it was unlikely that items that had an intersection with labor negotiations were likely to be closed during this legislative session.

I think that I am hearing from your colleagues and other colleagues in other larger Washington cities that there is definitely some movement to make sure that we discuss arbitration during this legislative session.
As I said, I think many of the reforms that are being discussed have already been adopted in Seattle.
If you go down that list, I do not know what the percentage would be.
I think it is quite high.
I am hearing applicants in community as well as Councilmembers and mayors around the state that some changes to arbitration would be extremely helpful to making significant change in our policing.
I do think that efforts will be made to pursue that during this legislative session.
Thank you.
Colleagues, any other questions or comments on the police reform aspects?
Okay, hearing none, Robin I know that you are having communications with many of my colleagues as you all are working on things together.
Your state legislative lobbying agenda, I think many issues you have highlighted in the area of police reform and accountability at the state level are critically important.
As you mentioned, Seattle has already implemented many of those proposals at the local level.
And so I do want to signal a strong support and I hope that those will become statewide standards.
This is with the understanding that they are not perfect mechanisms.
There could be some modification even at the state level from the standards that we have adopted.
I think that would be a wise exercise to do to sort of have a lesson's learned approach.
I think this would be wise.
And then, Secondly, as it relates to arbitration, I signaled, I communicated this to you all in our meeting.
That is a top priority for me as somebody who has been working in the area of police reform and accountability for well over 15 years.
I did this first as a civil rights attorney and now as a Councilmember.

The issues related to arbitration and whether it is binding or not binding and whether it is open or closed to the public, and how much value is placed on precedent versus review of issues; this is absolutely critically important to the issues related to public trust and confidence in our civilian led accountability system.
Arbitration has systematically I believe undermined, in the context of police unions, it has consistently undermined the public's confidence.
This is in accountability systems.
It deals with actually holding officers accountable.
This is for behaving in a way that is out of policy.
That to me is tragic, problematic, and it will continue to be, it will continue to be one the causes as to why the public has lost confidence in our accountability systems.
I think it is really, really important for us to be on the same page as it relates to what we want to see reformed in the arbitration process.
This relates to police unions and why.
I am willing to continue to work with you all on making sure that we are as aligned as we can be as a city.
Certainly, from the city council's perspective, this is an important issue.
Those of us who sit on the labor relation's policy committee have thoughts and ideas in this space.
We are continuing to explore that in that confidential setting.
We will always have conversations with people in order to make this a significant and top priority.
This is for the city.
Thank you very much Council President.
I do think that we will be calling you possibly more than usual for your support to move the arbitration regarding police reform forward in Olympia.
Thank you very much.
All right Robin, housing?
Do we want to dig into housing?
Housing, this will be fairly quick.
I know that you have a strong housing advocate here.
[Laughter] after many years at the office of housing, there are a number of proposals . I think we will be called on to work to protect some funding in housing areas.
This is given the budget and what is happening.
There will be a push . This is included on the legislative agenda.
This will significantly increase the document reporting fee that provides vital resources for homelessness.
There will be an investment of $250 Millionin the housing trust fund.
There will be rental assistance to prevent people who have been impacted by Covid-19 from losing their homes.

Also, you know, it will Memorialize some of the Eviction moratorium provisions to make sure that people do not lose their homes . Then of course, the office of housing has embarked on an ambitious proposal to create 600 units of supportive housing.
They are looking to the state to provide some our information and resources to support that.
Also, there are efforts to do more in the future.
There is a good cause Eviction proposal.
This will be on the legislative agenda to also support the statewide inaction of that.
We already have locally issues that will close loopholes that exist in the local legislation.
Foreclosure prevention and of course the housing justice act, it bans discrimination based on criminal records.
We are supporting that so that can be statewide.
And then Finally, you know, there is the overall budget production as I mentioned.
Thank you everyone.
If there are no questions on housing, we will go to our state relation's director.
Any questions on housing?
I see Councilmember Kshama Sawant.
If anybody else has questions, please.
Thank you.
First of all, I would like to say the Eviction's protections at the state level are very crucial.
I wanted to ask a couple of questions related to housing.
One is there has been a real call from Renters and also now working-class and middle-class homeowners who may have had long-term income loss or even job losses.
They want to understand what their fate is going to be once the moratoriums on the Eviction's expire.
So what conversations have there been at the state level among the elected officials about canceling rent, mortgage, and utility payments for all of this year?
This would prevent what analysts nationwide have said.
If we do not do that, then there will be a massive wave of Evictions when the moratoriums expire.
It is not just Seattle or Washington.
That is one question.
Let me go ahead and ask some of my other questions related to housing.
The other is the state invested what I think is a pitiful $175 million in housing.
This is over two years.
And so, what is the conversation there about any potential increases in funding for affordable housing?
I wanted to tie this to another thing that I will go ahead and mention.
You have not mentioned it unfortunately.
I think this is the main issue that is looming over the horizon.
I feel like the state Legislature should basically start with that.
This is the $4.2 billion by annual shortfall in the state budget.
So primarily, what is the conversation?
This is a larger question beyond housing.
What is the conversation about preventing these cuts, this shortfall from landing on ordinary people in the form of budget cuts?
This would be to services and housing that are already chronically underfunded.
Specifically, on housing, what is the proposal to make this when we are facing such a massive shortfall in the budget?
We need to prevent cuts to existing funds on housing.
How is that going to be tied to what is actually needed which is increasing the funds for housing?
Thank you so much Councilmember.
I think I will answer those questions in the order that you asked them.
The governor has convened a work group of both property owners and tenants and advocates.
They have been having discussions about what to do to address the Eviction moratorium ending.
I think that it is widely recognized that this is a very large problem.
I do not think anybody has the answers quite yet.
I also think that a lot of this also depends on as I said, you know, the Federal Government and providing additional resources for mental assistance.
You know, we did think that there would be another stimulus package coming through this fall.
With the election tomorrow, that did not happen.
I think that you know, everybody is kind of waiting to see the outcome of the election in order to see how many resources will be available.
I think under any circumstances, there is likely to be some additional stimulus funds.
Depending on the outcome, there is also wildly different scenarios of what might happen.
I think that lawmakers at the state level are waiting to see what happens there before they make additional decisions.
So, you know, it is certainly on the minds of many in Olympia and it is a significant issue of course.
You know, I think this falls under the Covid-19 relief umbrella.
If I did not give that enough Airtime, I apologize.
It is absolutely something that is considered very important.

As far as the investment in housing, you know, advocates at the housing alliance who we work very closely with our suggesting and they are signaling at this moment that there ask will be $250 million for the housing trust fund.
This is a little bit more than the 175 million.
I think that would be one the higher investments in the housing trust fund and the state level.

I will say that although of course, we would like to see more and more investment in housing at the state level, when the governor made cuts to the various line items on the budget in order to try and address the impacts that Covid- 19 was having on state revenue, he did not cut any housing or promises programs.
Almost no other area of the budget came out unscathed.
That was a signal of how important housing and homelessness is considered by state lawmakers, for sure.
And then, finally your last question, Quinn is going to talk a little bit more about the progressive revenue on our legislative agenda.
As I said, you know, lawmakers have not really come out with what their plan is.
We have talked with leadership on all of the Finance Committee's and appropriation's committees.
They have all assured us that there is no proposal that is off the table at the moment.
They are discussing you know, all sorts of different scenarios.
They have not shared exactly what their plan moving forward would be.
When will also talk about that a little bit more as part of his presentation coming up right now.
Councilmember Kshama Sawant, any follow-up questions?
I think I do but I think it would make sense for Quinn and others to speak and maybe later.
Okay, thank you Robin for those responses.
It sounds like we will head over to Quinn now.
Your name has been evoked a few times already.
Welcome, thank you for being with us this morning.
Take it away.
Thank you so much for having us.
So I am going to cover most of the remaining topics on the legislative agenda just to give sort of a preview of what we are looking at.
By way of background, the legislative agenda is our guiding document down in Olympia.
It provides the framework for us both as the values that we represent as a city but also the issues that we are allowed to lobby on.
As such, it is a broad document that includes a wide range of issues.
I am going to try to touch on the highlights of those broad issues and a couple specifics.
From the outside, I will just note that as we have been building this year's legislative agenda, we have used last year's as a base.
If there is an issue that you are passionate about and you feel it is important, it was in last year's legislative agenda and it is in this year paws.
The only reason it would not be is if it is no longer relevant.
For example, we have removed automated enforcement after the bill passed last year.
With that, I will go ahead and jump in.
I will try to just hit all of these highlights as quickly as possible.
We can take what I am sure will be a variety of questions.
Robin covered a few elements of Covid-19 recovery.
We have added a new section obviously as the city and communities around the country and the world grapple with the public health crisis that is Covid-19.
The city supports rental and Homeowner assistance to ensure that folks who are experiencing hardship are not thrown out of their homes.
The city supports utility assistance in order to ensure that heat and water access do not drive folks into poverty.
The city supports assistance for Undocumented immigrants.
Most Federal programs do not cover Undocumented immigrants Unfortunately.
The state recently announced relief funds and more can be done and should be done.
Finally, in this category, the city supports ensuring that business interruption insurance covers Covid-19.
Possibly the nose significant business interruption that business has ever experienced, apparently there are some insurance plans that do not.
We are working with the insurance Commissioner to make sure those are covered.
Moving on to progressive revenue, the city supports progressive state solutions that preserve critical programs well informing the upside down tax structure.
Obviously, this has been an issue that the city has been supportive of for many years.
I think it is more acutely felt now than ever with Covid-19.
Both the need for more progressive taxation and to reduce alliance on Regressive tax is important.
We want to ensure that funding for programs that serve our most needy populations and individuals that need the most support are preserved and expanded at the state level.

The city also supports maintaining and expanding local options for more progressive taxation as well as continued support for lifting the 1% cap on growth and property tax receipts that artificially curtail the city's budget . This allows us to more adequately respond to the issues that we have at the local level.
In education and early learning, the city supports full funding for public Ãšeducation.
That includes everything from Pre-K to protecting and expanding on K-12.
This includes improvements to higher education, free community and technical college.
The city supports expanding access and the availability of Childcare as well as increasing reimbursement rates with providers.
Many of these are struggling during the crisis as are many parents who need Childcare now or will need it when we eventually returned to work.
We want to make sure that those facilities and providers remain open after this crisis.
The next category is broadly economic justice and worker protections.
The city supports secure scheduling statewide.
There is a Misclassification of workers and portable benefits that move with workers between jobs.
The city supports extending important workplace protections through a domestic worker's bill of rights.
There needs to be help for immigrants regardless of documentation status.
There needs to be something that addresses regulatory hurdles.
Many of these are immigrants and they are experiencing issues in the community.
In criminal justice, the city supports easing the transition for previously incarcerated individuals and expanding diversion programs to direct offenders away from the Correctional system.
The city supports reforms to Dwl s 3. this is a technical term.
This deals with license suspensions from Non-Payments of traffic citations.
This forms an official cycle for folks who are in poverty.
They become trapped in poverty.

The city supports increasing protections for domestic violence victims, full funding to process the sexual assault kit backlog . We want protections for those who are working in sex work . We want consequences for those who are profiting from exploitation.
The city reports that they want to ease the barriers of entry for marijuana delivery.
We want to increase the licenses available to Black- owned businesses and increasing the ownership of those businesses.
We want to Redistribute Cannabis revenues to address the historical inequities caused by over policing marijuana offenses in certain communities.
In climate action and environmental justice, the city supports policies and programs that reduce greenhouse gas emissions broadly.

The city supports preserving and expanding programs that ensure clean water, Stormwater, management, talk to clean up and regulation and climate resiliency, especially for communities of color who have borne the brunt of environmental pollution.
The city's supports the expansion of availability of green space.
We want vehicle Electrification to meet climate goals.
In transportation, there is a new legislative agenda.
There is a new section that includes support for state funding for the West Seattle high bridge, repair or replacement.
This will Reconnect West Seattle to Seattle and the region.
It will Reconnect the court and the Maritime industrial areas to businesses and industries across the state.
The city also supports state funding proposals that include major proposals for active transportation and green transportation.
We want to expand local transportation revenue options, improving traffic safety for vulnerable users, and expanding the use of Nonuniform officers for traffic management.
I will pause there for questions.
I to want to have Hannah cover human services issues.
I will stop there and I will see if there are any questions on the wide ranging gamut of issues that we are expecting for the legislator.
Thank you Quinn.
Colleagues, do you have any questions or comments?
Councilmember Lisa Herbold, please.
Could you talk a little bit more in detail about what the transportation funds related options might be for addressing the closure of the West Seattle bridge?

Thank you for putting it within the context of not just to the needs of residents of West Seattle and the surrounding neighborhoods but also within a larger umbrella of regional needs associated with our economic issues.
Absolutely.
That is a good point.
I know that is a message that is important.
It is not just an asset for the city but it is an asset for the region and the state.
Just to clarify, did you want to hear more about the potential local transportation options or the options that the state is considering for a statewide transportation package?
All.
[Laughter]
Of course.
So, last year, several members in transportation considered various forms of a statewide transportation revenue package.
Senator Hobbs who is the chair of the Senate transportation committee put out a proposal that would have funded a wide variety of projects.
His proposal was predominantly funded by a carbon pricing system.
I think that there is a lot of interest in that as a revenue option.
This is at least as the predominant option in addition to you know, some of the more traditional vehicle weight fees.
And it deals with supplementary options.
There was also in that proposal a statewide commercial impact fee.
This is as well as a statewide Tmcp.
That is something we are always on the lookout for and aware of.
Representative Jake who is the chair of the House transportation committee has been holding a wide range of listening sessions this interim.
This is to develop a proposal that he is putting together.
This has included meetings with a whole range of Stakeholders.
The city of Seattle has participated in two of those.
They cover the range from labor to environmental activists to transit activists, to businesses and business communities.
They are really working to hear from everybody as they assemble their package.
And then, I know a handful of other legislators are considering various forms.
Or they are Prioritizing projects.
Obviously, last year, the West Seattle bridge was not yet the issue that we knew it to be.
So, the proposals from last year do not include it.
We are engaging with legislators to ensure that that does wind up in the proposals and it is something that is included.

Or if we reduce it at the city level, accounting can just scoop up the revenue from that so that the consumer is still paying the same sales tax.

This is an issue that is a little more complicated.
It does appear that there would be need to be a change in state law.
Currently, citizen County has almost a reciprocal sales tax authority.
If we reduced our sales tax, it would in effect be absorbed by King county by default.
So we would need to proceed with a change in state law to allow us to reduce our sales tax without it automatically being absorbed by the county.

Again, there is some threat to budget cuts there.

In behavioral health, there has been a lot of work being done by the behavioral health recovery system transformation task force.
That group includes legislators and staff.

This is for consideration in 2021.

The recommendations include some state oversight and coordination, workforce enhancements to encourage people to enter the behavioral health field, developing additional physical infrastructure so that there are options for more care settings and many other items.
So, we know that the human services safety net is one that people always rely on.
That is especially true now with increased economic struggles and other issues.
That is where we will be watching.
